name: hard coal mine operation | hard coal, run-of-mine | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18382/documentation

The dataset represents the production of 1 Kg hard coal for India. The data values for the dataset is taken from annual reports and other environment statements from Coal India Limited. The activity starts from extraction of coal present under the rock to final loading into vehicles to be sent for transportation. The coal transported here is either directly sent to the users or some amount of the coal (very less amount, less than 5% of total production) is sent to coal preparation facilitites.;The estimated coal reserves in India were 308.80 billion tons as on 31.03.2016. The coal deposits in India are mainly confined to eatern and south central parts of the country.The states of Jharkhand, Odisha, Chattisgarh, West Bengal , Madhya Pradesh , Telangana and Maharashtra account for 98.58 % of the total coal reserve in the country.;India is currently among the top three fastest growing economies of the world. As a natural corollary India's energy needs too are fast expanding with its increased industrialization and capacity addition in Power generation. This is where 'Coal' steps in. In India coal is the critical input for major infrastructure industries like Power, Steel and Cement.;;;;Coal is the most dominant energy source in India's energy scenario.;Coal meets around 55% of primary commercial energy needs in India against 29% the world over.;Around 70% of India's power generation is coal based.;India is the 3rd largest coal producing country in the world after China and USA.;Coal India Limited (CIL) as an organized state owned coal mining corporate came into being in November 1975 with the government taking over private coal mines. CIL Produces around 84% of India's overall coal production;The emission data for emissions to air and emissions to land have been taken from global datasets. 

Mining process starting from hard coal, in ground.

The activity ends with 1 kg coal at the coal mine. The data set includes electricity consumption, fuel consumption, explosives , emissions to air and water as well as overburden (or spoil ) removed while extracting coal.
Hard coal preparation is not a part of this activity.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data Collected are collected over the years 2006 - 2016 , They are estimated to be valid till 2020. The data collected has been taken from the annual reports from 2014-15 and statistics of mines in India Volume - 1 (Coal ) for the year 2014 and several other environmental statements available for various mines in india
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Region specific.; The coal deposits in India are mainly confined to eatern and south central parts of the country.The states of Jharkhand, Odisha, Chattisgarh, West Bengal , Madhya Pradesh , Telangana and Maharashtra account for 98.58 % of the total coal reserve in the country.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Most of coal production in India comes from opencast mining , contributing to almost 90 - 92% while the underground mining is just in the range of 7-8%.;Technology in place for opencast mining: shovel -dumper, dragline, in-pit crushing and conveying, surface miners;Technology in place for underground mining: conventional and mechanised Bord and Pillar with SLD (Side Load Discharge), LHD (Load Haul Dumpers) ; Powered support longwall, continuous miner;The Current data represents the current technology levels prevalent in the coal mine operations in the country and has been collected from both opencast as well as underground mining.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data is collected from various secondary sources available. Various annual reports from Coal India Limited , Ministry of Coal  were used for collection of the data. Some Environmental statments were also used for data collection.Some of the data points like spoil , methane emissions , explosives, have a representativeness of more than 80 % of coal mines in India. Some other data like diesel, electricity the representativeness is a little less around 20-25%. For the remaining data like land transformation and occupation data have been taken from only few mines (< 5 %). The emissions to air (other than methane) and emissions to land have been taken from the global datasets. The emission value for the air and water emissions have been kept same as in the global data set without any proportions done accorfing to the technology. Methane has been calcualted from the emission factors available at the GHG platform India 2005-2013 National Estimates - 2017 Series and have been proportioned according to the technology levels.

exchanges.description: Data from "hard coal mine operations and hard coal preparation"/GLO 2002 (accessed 20170825) has been used as no local Indian data on this exchange are available.
Data from "hard coal mine operations and hard coal preparation"/GLO 2002 (accessed 20170825) has been used as no local Indian data on this exchange are available.

Estimated Value : The above data is taken from Environment statements of two open cast mines namely Rajmahal open cast mine and Chitra (east) open cast mine. 50 % of the total land is assumed to be used for extraction and other 50% to be used as dump site.To calculate land occupation mine life was taken as 20 years as mentioned in the environment statment and additional 100 years were considered for revegetation of the mine.

Calculated value based on literature values. The water details are mentioned in an android app by Western coal fields limited.                                   The water is discharged from mines , the same water is used for process, drinking purpose (both industrial and domestic), The water after treatment is also sent to near by locations for agricultural and drinking purpose. The remaining water is charged into the ground. Water to air is calculated to be for evaporation and is considered at 15 % of the total water discharged from mine.
Data from "hard coal mine operations"/GLO (accessed 20170825) has been used as no local Indian data on this exchange are available.

exchanges.description:
Literature Data: Values Taken from Coal India Limited and Singareni Colleries Company Limited annual reports where the production values of coal is given along with the overburden (spoil ) generted from the same.

The above data for Coal India Limited and Singareni Colleries Company Limited consitutes around 93.37 % of total coal produced in india.

The data available for the exchange was in cubic meter so to convert into kg the density was taken as 1.648 Kg/cubic meter

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Data from "hard coal mine operations and hard coal preparation"/GLO 2002 (accessed 20170825) has been used as no local Indian data on this exchange are available.                                                                  Estimation. Regarding underground mines it is assumed that apart from electricity and diesel consumption also other energy carriers are required. For simplification reasons the consumption of other energy carriers is considered in this module. 

Energy consumption of other energy carriers (apart from diesel and electricity) is not estimated in Hinrichs. However, energy consumption of 110 MJ/ t usable output regarding underground mines is included in the dataset. 

Further references:

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Germany.

exchanges.description:
Estimation based on available emission factors for Coal mining in India. 

Following are the emission factors available for India. Methane Emission factor for opencast mining in India (cubic meter / ton of coal mined) is 1.18 for mining operation and 0.15 for post mining activities (handling). 

Similarly for underground mining, the emission factors are dependent on the category of mines. So for a Degree-I mine the emission factor for mining activity is 2.91 (cubic meters per ton) and for post mining activity it is 0.98 (cubic meter per ton). For Degree-II mine the emission factor for mining activity is 13.08 (cubic meters per ton) and for post mining activity it is 2.15 (cubic meter per ton). For a Degree-III mine the emission factor for mining activity is 23.68 (cubic meters per ton) and for post mining activity it is 3.12 (cubic meter per ton).Production of coal from underground mines is estimated to be equally divided into degree-I, Degree-II and Degree - III mines.

The above emission factors are taken from GHG platform India 2005-2013 National Estimates - 2017 Series. These can be referred in a excel file available at http://www.ghgplatformindia.org/electricityenergy-sector  under the section Download: Phase 2 (2005- 2013) National Level Estimate.

The density of methane is taken as 0.68 Kg/cubic meter, the same value is taken while converting from meter cube to kg. The same is also mentioned in the above source.

The total production of coal for the year 2015-16 was 639.234 million tons, out of which approx. 7.26% is from underground mines and remaining 92.739% is from opencast mines. These values have been used proportionately with respective emission factors to come up with the final value for methane in the dataset.
